content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Telltale makes genre games, and this is one of those. I feel like it's solidly representative of pre-Walking Dead Telltale- kind of a mediocre-to-good game that never really impresses. It's a 5 episode series, about 10-12 hours in length. It's a point and click adventure game with some QTE-ish action sequences sprinkled around. It's never really challenging but sometimes interesting.The plot's decent, typical hop-around-in-time BTTF faire, but they manage to make the gameplay pretty samey despite the time difference. The high point is probably the whole dystopian-future Citizen Brown plot, which is a pretty decent departure from the tone of the series. Maybe that's why it works.The music is great, of course, it's the BTTF soundtrack, but it really starts to wear out its welcome the 20th time you hear the main theme or "back.. in.. time.." They managed to find a voice actor who can do a pretty passable Marty, even.The game's loaded with fanservice, so I'd say that if you're a fan of BTTF it's easily worth a play, and that you might not enjoy it very much if you aren't. The gameplay isn't that great to carry interest beyond that.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												If you are looking for adventure games like those of the golden age of point and clicks  games from Lucas Arts and Sierra  this is as close as you are going to get.  Telltale Games is one of the master of this new era of what is adventure games.  With what amounts to a Seqeul to the Back to the Future movies, they  have managed to make the gameplay fun and enjoyable while balancing it with a nod to fanboys of the movies.(Which is always a difficult thing to do)  The voice acting is awesome and the fact that they managed to get some of the actors from the original movie to reprise their roles for the game was beyond amazing. The story is original and I loved the intro that tied in to the the movie.  I wish this title had achievements.  But other than that for those who want more of back to the future or have a need for adventure games.  Wish there was a sequel to this game sadly more and more unlikely as time goes on.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												I really wanted to give episode 1 a 'thumbs down'. I don't want to turn people off to the game though. As a whole, the BttF game is great. Episode 1... is not.There are many problems. Generally related to bugs. I experienced them constantly in episode one. (Luckily none of these appear in the other episodes!) I have a lot of complaints. That will be the focus of this review. However, I still recommend the game as it has a great deal of entertainment value.Often I would be unable to click on certain people or objects. The game would randomly decide I hadn't clicked on what I clearly did click upon. Instead, it would pick a random clickable person/object instead. Sometimes mouseover caused odd results. The pop-up text (on-screen description) would rapidly flash between what was highlighted by the cursor, and a nearby object.The dialog trees are all messed up. It seems like a part of the story was removed... or maybe it's just bugged. I'm not sure. I would frequently find that the dialog I was part of was way ahead of the story. Events (cutscenes) were always in order. The dialog rarely was.The story itself, is good. It is very much a BttF-style story. The character models were given a distinctly cartoony appearance. There is also a lot of adult humor. (The kind you should expect based on the film series.) This is sharply contrasted with the fact that the characters look like they originated in a modern animated film. (See: The Incredibles, Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, Frozen, etc.) They kind-of look like anime versions of the real-life actors of 'Back to The Future'.The mouse controls are poor. You have to hold Left-Mouse-Button(LMB), then drag to make your character walk. If you want to run, you have to hold RMB. However, if you hold RMB before you hold LMB, then you don't run. I can use the keyboard to walk, but I'm not sure how to run. Which means I'm stuck using the mouse for just about everything in this game.Probably the most disappointing thing is that animation was reused from the 'Sam & Max' games. Marty walks with the exact same motions as Sam. When people are talking, their mannerisms will follow the same patterns used in 'Sam & Max'.Lastly I want to mention that if you have a Nvidia card, you'll need to turn on 'Antialiasing - Transparancy'. If you don't, the shadows will look terrible. Personally, I find them so bad that it distracts me from the game. Then again... it might just be my particular video card. You never know.Most of these problems do not carry to the subsequent episodes. So, I happily recommend this.

Posted: May 27, 2016
												Time Period of Review:FridayMay 262016While my Dad seems to like the Back to the Future Movie Series, I think Telltale have done a great job with their Point and Click Adventure Games, Back to the Future: The Game or Back to the Future: Part 4 is by far a neat game which contains Time Travel. Set 6 months after the events of the third film, the DeLorean Time Machine mysteriously returns to Hill Valley driverless. Travel through time as you meet up with McFlys, Tannens and Browns through the ages to right wrongs, amend timelines, and prevent terrible terrible mistakes by going up to 88MPH & Who needs roads we're When going to.Episode 1:Marty McFly is just getting re-acquainted with the 1980’s when the DeLorean Time Machine he saw destroyed by a speeding train materializes before him. He finds out that Doc Brown is trapped somewhere in the past and that he must travel back in time to save the Doc's future!Episode 2:Marty is keeping an eye on young Doc Brown's proverbial date with scientific destiny when he and 1980s Doc must prevent gang boss Kid Tannen from wreaking havoc on Marty's family and erasing his girlfriend from the future! Episode 3:A time-stranded Marty has a rough and tumble return to the 1980s and finds himself in a topsy-turvy or should we say Politically Corrected version of the world lorded over by the enigmatic "First Citizen Brown." Episode 4:The Hill Valley Expo has arrived! Back in 1986, Marty and First Citizen Brown must join forces to create an epic invention so that he can prevent the young Emmett Brown from making the worst mistake of his life.Episode 5:In the Series Finale of Back to the Future: Part 4, lives are changed, mysteries are solved, and paradoxes are avoided as Young Emmett seals his fate, sending Marty and Doc on a climactic chase through Hill Valley's past, present, and future.

												If you are a fan  of BTTF and have played other Telltale Games and have enjoyed them, then this is a no brainer. I have played through all 3 seasons of Telltale's Sam & Max games, so BTTF: The Game felt like familiar territory. So far, I have completed the first 2 episodes of this point-and-click adventure series, and I have enjoyed them. The story is well written, picking up where the movie triology left off, and feels like it fits quite naturally with the movie story line. The plotline is very much in line with the movies, where time travel inadvertently, and disastrously, messes up the time line, which then needs fixing. This time, Marty and Doc need to visit Prohibition-era Hill Valley to fix history. The voice acting is pretty good and the actor portraying Marty does a pretty good Michael J. Fox impression.Now on to my gripes...the puzzles are very sensical but they are almost too easy; at times it's almost spelled out for you what you need to do. So far I haven't needed to use the game's built in hint system. Next, the navigation in the game's quasi-3D environments is frustrating. Getting Marty to negotiate his way around the scenery is clunky. This game has the same annoying navigation that was introduced in the last season of the Sam and Max games.Other than those 2 gripes, these games are enjoyable for BTTF fans who want more stories with the characters they love and who, are interested in exploring more lore about Hill Valley, the McFlys, and the Tannens. Oh, we also get to see Doc when he was much younger.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												Back to the Future: The Game serves as a well written sequel to the cult film franchise.The game is a classic Telltale game, 3rd person adventure style with controllable walking and interactive objects while moving the plot forward. The plot across the five episode are well thought out. Marty travels to 1931 to find Doc, who has disappeared and is delcared dead in 1986. The main events of the game take place in alternate time period of 1931 and 1986 while also unraveling mysters of Hill Valley. And in the end, everything is actually tied up, from Edna and Tannen to discovering who Trixie Trotter really is and meating Marty's ancestors. The game does leave an ambiguity for a possible second season that Telltale haven't opened up about....yet.The graphics are pretty standard for Telltale, a soft textures and average polygon models that sometimes look a little off. It does give a vibe of adventure in the style of how the characters were modeled though, I really like how Marty and Doc turned out.Music and audio are great, nothing too special about them though.Overall, this serves as a great add-on to the films and are just as scientific with theories new and old. Great game.9.0/10

Posted: December 21, 2013
												I started playing this game after playing Telltale's, The Walking Dead. The same company behind the awesome zombie story game helped create this game. For fans of Back to the Future trilogy movies, this is a must, as the story continues right after the events of the end of the 3rd movie, where the Delorean is destroyed. However, this is not a pure action game. It plays exactly like Telltale's The Walking Dead, so it's at your own pace solving your way through the game's storyline. Some can be turned off by that but I happen to enjoy it, especially since the story is great and the world of the Back to the Future franchise brings back so many nostalgic memories.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Apparently, from what I hear from other fellow "reviewers", this is one of those Telltale games before the heavy-hitters like "The Walking Dead" and "The Wolf Among Us", and as such, you would expect certain nuances of this game, contextual to its development, compared to the general expectations these days.Having said that, I'm not a big graphics man, and I generally don't expect too much when it comes to these point-and-click adventure games. But it's Back to the Future! Made by Telltale! And has Doc's original actor (Christopher Lloyd, from what I recall)! So what's not to love? Unless you're not a BTTF fan, or just hate the game in general.The premise of the game is to explore Doc's disappearance, requiring you to go back in time and find him in some time in the past. From there, the plot kind of goes in some strange but enjoyable turn of events, thus propelling your role to fix up time paradoxes and whatnot, so the future normalises itself. So plot-wise, the game seems to make sense mostly. Characters aren't too detailed, but you can make sense of what they're like, which is important in some parts of the episodes. But the plot starts to get interesting from Episode 3 onwards, especially that part where you have to mess up young Doc's love life.Controls can get a bit weird with the camera panning around sometimes, so you might find the down button moves you left, and some others unusual orientation of movements.Now, I played the "Wallace and Gromit" games (were they made by Telltale as well?), and what I mainly don't like in these episodes is the item panel system. In "Wallace and Gromit", you'd just right click to bring up your items and pick something out. Here, you have to click on the item icon, pick your item, and if you need to pick out another item, you have to do the process again. Sure, you're never really using objects mostly, but it is always nice to hotkey these things.Additionally, some items never actually serve a useful purpose and kind of just loiter around your item space. I guess red herrings are interesting, but if you're stuck in a certain part of the game, you might think these items are useful, but the're not. So be aware of that, but at least they disappear (mostly) in the next episode.Also, walking speeds are a bit slow. I found that holding Shift makes you "run", which is just a sped-up animation of Marty with a slight speed increase. In certain areas, you will actually run, and even so, if you phase out of an area, you have to re-hold the Shift key again to "run". A bit of a pain, but it's manageable.The puzzles are interesting to solve, like that guitar battle with Leech, the SoupMo guy, where you can't actually beat him in skill, but you have to sabotage his performance and win that way. In some instances, you'll be likely to be in a situation where you're wondering "What do I do now? I've done mostly everything... What am I missing?". Here, hints can come in handy. I've only ever had to use the hints once (mostly due to my adamance of finding the solution myself), but sometimes it can really get to you and make you kinda rage at the game, because you don't know what to do next.And some instances, you'll actually solve the puzzle using sheer coincidence, where your actions just happpen to fall together into a solution that works out. But mostly, you'll have to recall certain information and use objects to help you coordinate the environment to your will and get things done.In terms of play time, each episode took around 2-3 hours each, which equates to about 10-15 hours to finish the series. So if you're a casual player with a few hours to spare, I guess this is one avenue to spend your time on. See what I did there, eh? But $24.99 is a little steep for only 15 hours, I suppose. You might want to wait until this is on special (I got it in a Humble Bundle) or something. But in short, I'd give this a 7/10. Not too bad, but still a bit rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Product received for free
Was travelling through time:WingOne basic thing, I've never watched a Back to the Future movie, so I can only think that game is based on a film.Back to the Future is point-&-click game made by Telltale Games, as we all know, it must be episodic, game itself has 5 episodes that were released from 22 December 2010 to 23 June 2011. Game action takes place in fictional city Hill Valley. Here's the list of episodes and short description of what is going in them(I will try to include as little amount of spoilers as I can)It's About Time - We begin game in 1986, but when we find out our best friend is missing, we are looking for him, after that, we are going back in time to 1931 to rescue our friend! Get Tannen! - When everything seems ok, our friend finds out that our grandfather is going to die and we need to rescue him AND make the most dangerous criminal in Hill Valley, will go to jail!Citizen Brown - Everything looks fixed, everyone is happy (except that one guy in jail), but then! We are transported to Future Hill Valley or Pure Hill Valley or, as I prefer to say Alternate Hill Valley. In this episode we need to make problems in Pure Hill Valley to meet Citizen Brown and convince that HIS Hill Valley is bad and people are unhappy!Double Visions - After rescuing Citizen Brown and destroying his ideal vision of sad Hill Valley we need to rescue him again from his enraged wife, then go back in time to 1931 to find his younger self and convince him to break up with his future wife, after that is done, episode ends.OUTATIME! - We are still in 1931 and we must find Younger Brown his older self kidnapped him and then we must take care that Younger one, will do his presentation at Science Expo. After that, everything seems ok, but then! The Woman who broke with Brown, stole his DeLorean and went back in time, and we need to find out to what date she travelled, after that, we are going to 19th Century to stop arson of the Saloon and in consequence, destruction of wholeHill Valley. In the end, we must manipulate with stolen DeLorean and then make sure that she'll land in 1931... And in the end is kinda funny plot twist but discover it by yourself :)And now's time for few most important characters:Marty McFly - Main protagonist, time traveler, also known as Sonny Crockett, Yakov SmirnoffEmmett 'Doc' Brown  - Best friend of Marty, time traveler, inventor, also known as Carl Sagan - The Infamous ArsonistEdna Strickland - And here are 2: - Young Edna - Cute, manipulating, desiring power and control over people She's the real arsonist - Old Edna - Alone, miserable, spends days on yellingBiff Tannen - Typical bully, in the right timeline he works for Marty's father.Arthur McFly - Only seen in 1931, our Grandfather, he makes kinda big role in Marty adventureKid Tannen - The most dangerous gangster in 1931, he needs to be arrested (Episode 2)Einstein - Our cute and lovely dog <3 Citizen Brown also known as Alternate Emmett - He thinks that HIS Hill Valley is perfect, we need to convince him that this city is Town of fearCitizen Edna also known as Alternate Old Edna - Manipulates with Alternate Emmett, after Marty destroys her husband's vision of perfect city, she tries to manipulate with his memoryYoung Emmett - Young inventor, feared of his dad, in sick love with EdnaTrixie Trotter also known as 'Sylvia' - Our (unknowingly until end of game) Grandmother, speakeasy stage performer, cuteLet's see how it looks...Gameplay - 8/10 - Typical point-&-click, with annoying camera sometimes, yet still, gameplay is greatAudio - 6/10 - Not bad, not good, decent, BUT with soundtrack from movie I thinkGraphics - 8/10 - Nice, clear, not-eye hurting, except characters sometimes look like dead (I mean, without emotions)Story - 10/10 - Great! Just Great!OVERALL - 8/10 - Game itself has a few bugs here and there, and sometimes can be harder or easier, but this is one, great, funny story with lovely characters and with unfortunately decent audio, I can recommend it for fans of point-&-click or Telltale Games loversGreetings, Wing

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												First of all, i dont exactly recommend this game, i just cant say its horrible. I didnt really enjoy it verry much, and this is not due to the few graphical issues encountered or the awfull controller support. Its a  classic point-and-click adventure, and it picks up shortly after the film trilogy ends, as you play Marty McFly going back in time to 1930s prohibition-era to save Doc from his latest pickle. The game rests on a fun plot and sharp dialogue in a beautifully recreated Hill Valley, with terrific voice acting featuring many from the original cast, yet ultimately, it's sadly let down by lightweight in-game puzzles that lack invention and complexity. My real frustration though is that I'm a  100% sure  that Telltale can do better than this. You can still give it a shot, as i said the game is not horrible, but it is overpriced for sure. You could easily pick a much more entertaining game for this price.

You can hear static on the higher notes in the dialogue, no idea if it's the way the audio was recorder or if it's a bug in the game. Overall, this game is VERY representative of Telltale's "expertise" in game development, I was equally unimpressed by The Walking Dead, despite the raving reviews. Only The Wolf Among Us looks and feels like a finished product that's worth any money (but not $20 mind you, it's way too short). Why these guys make such a killing with their games and get such good reviews is beyond me.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Intro:I honestly thought I would just be replaying the movies. It is aptly named Back to the Future: "THE GAME." There is enough material in the first 30 minutes of gameplay to warrant a weekly Television Show. With that said, if you haven't seen the movie (WTF? - It is possible I am told.) Go see it first. The game story relies HEAVILY on the fact that you've seen the movie 'more than once.' It is absolutely made for fans of the movie and not designed for people who will not get the references. You could play it and solve the puzzles but it wouldn't be half as fun. In my opinion this was definitely made for die-hards as expressed in the tremendous detail and love of the franchise. xD~Game Review: (pros and cons)Graphics: "Cartoony" style. Simple and quaint. A cool twist on beloved characters.Sound: Fantastic! High Quality. The voices are stellar and when the theme hits it gives you goose bumps.  Interface: Point, Click and Grab. Simple and straight forward. Dialogue text. ... Clever Puzzles. Object Manip. (*Note: Some people have reported sporatic issues of not being able to: ? - move to a certain spot, problem clicking and/or manipulating a certain item/element in the game world, etc. Obviously if this occurs on an object needed to continue the story it would be a major problem. ~ I myself have thankfully not encountered any of these issues.)Story: Here's the kicker for me... I bought this game as a die-hard fan with an open mind of expecting any and everything. (Mild Spoiler Upcoming...) In the first 30 seconds, I thought I was simply going to be replaying the game (it was just the intro... duh xD~) and I was fully satisfied with the thought that I would just be playing out the movies. ~ It's Not. ~ It is a totally unique and original story. There is enough material in this game to write an entire Television Drama series. From the best Sci-Fi that we are all familiar with; Guess what? As George Lucas found out the hard way... It's not the pretty graphics, it's not the 3D interface with a bunch of peripheral toys, it's not the high priced actors and the gorgeous women. What is the 'IT' Factor that makes something so spectacular? It's the writing. Always has been, always will be. And this game HAS IT! =) If the writing sucks, the 'whatever it is' tanks. It's that simple. You can throw all the money in the world at something but if you don't pay someone with a brain five bucks to write a good story, people are going to know it and they are going to know it QUICK. Unfortunately in these days, =) like plutonium, good writers are a 'little hard to come by.' xD~ What is/was a $10 steam sale game; hits upon a Serious IDEA. They only made three movies. This should Really be made into a TV television series drama. (NBC/Universal I'm talking to YOU!) Quantum Leap part 2 so to speak. Guy who bounces through time with his buddy. They already have all of it; it's all on the Paramount lot, even the costumes. It would take nothing more than a producer with the nerve. I'm sure there's a demand. All of the cost is taken care of because the props are all there. It would be... SO EASY it's unbelievable. The only thing they NEED: are Writers. =) So... you heard it here. xD~ To be cliche: Well, here's hoping the idea doesn't magically vanish. At least 'The Future' is: whatever we make it, so we'll have to make it a Good One, ALL of US! ~ Enjoy Life the best you can, wherever you are, because we're all stuck In "Good'Old" Two Thousand and Fifteen.Conclusion:If you don't have B2tF: The Series to watch on NBC...the next best thing is to play "Back to the Future: The GAME"5 Stars. 10/10. Thumbs Up.Highly Recommended.

												Very poorly optimized, lip sync is off, the art style of the characters clashes with the semi-realistic textures and proportions of the environment, but the sound quality is what ruined the game for me. You can hear static on the higher notes in the dialogue, no idea if it's the way the audio was recorder or if it's a bug in the game. Overall, this game is VERY representative of Telltale's "expertise" in game development, I was equally unimpressed by The Walking Dead, despite the raving reviews. Only The Wolf Among Us looks and feels like a finished product that's worth any money (but not $20 mind you, it's way too short). Why these guys make such a killing with their games and get such good reviews is beyond me.

Product received for free
												Not my cup of tea at all. If there is one thing I do not like it is games full of cut scenes and boring dialogue.  Unfotunately that is all this game comprises of. Was never a big 'fan' of the movies and only have this game because I was gifted it.The graphics and  especially the audio suit the game down to a tee, but unfortunately the gameplay and the mediocre puzzles just do not float my boat. The puzzles I had to solve in my short stint all seemed to rely on trial and error. That just does not cut the mustard with me, I would prefer something that had a logical solution. I am guessing that this game is aimed at younger peope.While not a terrible game in any respect, I cannot find myself recommending it to anyone. This is the first Telltale game I have played, so I don't know if this is their usual modus operandi. If so, then I suppose that if you like their other games you may like this. As for myself, I will be uninstalling episode 1 and will not be installing any of the others in a hurry. This will go into my 2 star category, and maybe if I am bored enough one day, I might take another look just to see it through to the end.

Posted: December 5, 2015
												If you had played the recent telltales games and wondering if this is the same.. no! its not!The recent telltales games from walking dead onwards are really more of a story and choice selection game. The story goes on and your character moves as per story unfolds. There are only few situation where you get to actually control your character to move around.However, this is more of a story puzzle game, where you actually control your character almost all the time to solve puzzle and then the story moves on to another puzzle. I am at the near end of episode one and I got really bored as I am expecting more of the recent type of game telltales have but sadly it isnt.So save your money for other titles if you are looking for the same as what I am looking for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2011
												If you've loved the Back to the Future Trilogy for decades as I have, this game will NOT disappoint! Christopher Lloyd reprises his role as Doc Brown, and while Michael J. Fox allowed his likeness to be used for the game, he wasn't able to reprise his role... but the guy they got to impersonate him is eerily good.The game is a point and click puzzle adventure and while the controls can be a little irritating at times, the sheer joy the BTTF universe brings me makes it easy to overlook. This is a new, original story which takes place after the third film in the trilogy. While I haven't yet figured out how the DeLorean suddenly exists again after getting smashed by a train just outside Eastwood Ravine, I've only played through the first two episodes, so I am assuming that explanation is forthcoming... along with why Doc Brown is in 1931 (he mentions this in Episode 2 when Marty asks, but says he'll explain when they've set the time streams back to normal once more.)Tons of fun!

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												as a fan of the movies its hard to get into Back to the future games. over the years various ones have came out and most of them were garbage. Now i wished there was 3 options to choose for a review for games such as neutral. there are sometimes where we feel a game was decent but lacked on certain things. for me this is one of them. I enjoyed the voice acting. The story was not too bad. I'm one of those people that came off playing Walking Dead, Wolf among us, Game of Thrones before this game. So i was thinking there would be something similar.  But i tried their game Sam and max before this one so then i realized not all of their games would be like that. First thing that annoyed me was the controls and the camera. this was using a 360 controller. Sometimes it wouldn't react or i couldn't figure out what to use my buttons on. So i would have to actually use my mouse. So that defeated the controller purpose. the game being broken into 5 titles is only a small annoyance.So i only did complete one chapter atm but im mixed at the game. I'm not sure if this will be one i will finish because of the controls and camera annoying me. Now don't get me wrong if you can get it to work then it might not be so bad. i can't recommend this at full price. bundle or major sale maybe.

												The game would be nice if it wasn't so glitchy.Having startup issues when changing resolution and switching to full screen, bad controller support, terrible camera movement. Sometimes you'll be walking forward, then the camera will switch directions and you'll start walking in the opposite direction. The controller has lost functionality. You can see that they tried to add controller support, but it's incomplete. You can't use inventory items with a controller, you must use a cursor, so that's a lost functionality.Weird dialogue glitches where the camera will be behind a wall and you can't see the characters.If they fixed these issues, made the camera movement flow better instead of randomly flipping directions, and completed the controller functionality, it would be a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												This game was great! My favorite part is when you're using the sonic screwdriver, and you're all like "ZAP ZAP" and the Cybermen are all electrocuted, and- Wait... This is the Back to the Future game? Why didn't you tell me?Now don't get me wrong. I LOVE the Back to the Future trilogy. It's literally one of my favorite movie series.Yet, this game just didn't really stick out to me.*Pros*: Somewhat interesting story, okay voice acting, kinda funny characters, and simple game mechanics.*Cons*: Controls are buggy (Making Marty seem like a bit of a derp...), the camera is spastic, the dialouge can be tedious, and this isn't the game's fault, but more the company who made it. (TellTale games.) No matter what you do, it's just one path. No decisions, nothing. Just walking around... It just gets a bit dull. Overall, I wouldn't really recommend this game if you're looking for a fun adventure game. If you're a die hard BTTF fan or it's really cheap on Steam, then you should probably get this game. (Provided you don't mind the controls.)6.95/10 Stars

												'Wait a minute, Doc. Ah... Are you telling me that you built a time machine... out of a DeLorean?''The way I see it, if you're gonna build a time machine into a car, why not do it with some *style?'Back to the Future: The Game is an adventure puzzle point-and-click game from Telltale Games, based on the Back to the Future movies.The game consists of five episodes and most of the time you are in search for items, people or information to solve the puzzles in order to make progress through the story.Good to know is that this game has some voice-overs from the original movie cast involved.The game is so strong and well written that it fits well within the Back to the Future movie itself.This game also felt like the nostalgic atmosphere from the Ghostbusters video game from 2009.If my calculations are correct, this game with all her five episodes are really worth playing.Buy the game, if it's not on sale anymore, go back in time! content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												If you're a fan of the BTTF franchise (I haven't met anyone who isn't), then you'll enjoy guiding your favorite characters through a story that more-or-less captures the feel of the series. It's a little more Saturday-morning-cartoony in both visual style and tone, but the vibe is pretty much there. The puzzles can be a little too simple or revolve around finding some random object, two or three areas away, which gets a bit annoying. Not challenging but still fairly enjoyable. Play it for the story.

Posted: September 6, 2016
												To call this game uninspired fails to encompass the issue, but it's the first word that comes to mind. The second is "cash-in." There's a chance that the true, diehard BttF fan will enjoy revisiting the property enough to forgive the lack of interesting gameplay, original story, decent voice acting, or really anything but fanwank circling the drain, but for anyone that only liked BttF (and more so those who didn't like it) give it a miss.

Posted: July 8, 2015
												I believe that this is the best representation of Back to the Future you could ever ask for in a Video Game. There are many laughs, interesting characters as well as old ones being acted brilliantly and, just like the origonal series, what starts out as a simple action to fix things with the time machine makes things far worse. I origonally bought this as soon as it came out on the PS3 as a percentage went to a charity for parkinsons, which Michael J Fox unfortunatly suffers from.This is a labor of love and that's obvious when playing this game. I highly recommend it to any fan of back to the future.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												I picked this up as part of the Telltale Games pack when it was on sale. I was mainly after the Sam & Max series so this was more of a bonus than anything.Having finally got around to playing it I have to admit it's much better than I thought it would be. The attention to detail and the sympathetic way they have stayed faithful to the original premise makes it a pleasure to play. The story is fairly well constructed and (without giving too much away) the way the series ending pokes fun at itself made me chuckle. The whole series doesn't take itself too seriously and that is to its credit.The good bits: The voice acting is superb. Christopher Lloyd! Even though Marty wasn't voiced by MJ Fox (who does do some cameos) I would not have known without looking. It is that good. The story holds together well with some nice plot twists not all of which are obvious.  It's a Telltale point-and-click adventure which I tend to like anyway. It doesn't penalise you for exploring or even trying something stupid. Fans of the films are going to appreciate the faithful reproduction of the BTTF universe with plenty of references to film trivia.The bad bits: The graphics aren't exactly photo realistic but they are good enough in a cartoon spin-off way. Some of the puzzles are just a case of going through the motions rather than any significant problem solving ability. I don't think you'll get stuck very often so if it's a challenge you want then this might not be it. Each episode is probably only 2 or 3 hours of gameplay depending on how many of the dialogue options you explore.If you like this type of game then you could do far worse. If there were a second season I would buy it although I might still yearn for a little more depth to the puzzles.  As I'm generally a miser when it comes to paying for games I'd say its full price is a little too high, but if you like this sort of game and see it in the sale I'd go for it. Recommended.

												I am a HUGE fan of the Back to the Future Trilogy so I decided to try out the games. I found them quite fun but the amount of times I shouted at the screen because the character models and their animation is over 9000. Even though the animation wasn't the best in the world I still enjoyed the games a lot. The only other problem I found was that the first four games I found quite a bit harder than "Outatime" the fifth instalment to the series. This game was very bad and the fact the SPOILERS Edna was the speakeasy artist was a cool idea but WHY IN THE WORLD DID THE GAME DESIGNERS THINK "ooh I know lets get Edna to steal a time machine" This made the fifth game short and boring and unlike the other games which took a total of atleast 3 or 4  hours, apart from the second game "Get Tannen", other a long period of time I was able to complete "Outatime" in 2 and a half hours. This disapointed me ;( but I would still look past that and recommend this series of games to any of my Back to the Future loving friends!!

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Yeah, so, my game time isn't accurate. I forgot I had it open! Anyway, I'd say the total game time for one episode was right around 2 hours. This is an older episode game from Telltale and it does show, to a degree. The Telltale engine works well and it has carried them on through recent releases, and it holds up rather well in that respect. In this, you can set your expectation to what you would (in terms of graphics) for a game released around this time - it looks pretty good, but certainly not what we expect in 2014, but still fun to look at! Some things haven't held up this well, at all. The good and the bad are in equal supply with this, I think it looks adorable and the characters and voice acting are fantastic. Telltale really has a talent for making things like Back To The Future, The Wolf Among Us, The Walking Dead, etc., really come to life and be fun again. The light touchings of "pick your own adventure" stylings were already perfected in that "Telltale Games" way, even when this came out. The biggest negative to this I have to give to the controls. They're clumsy. Extremely clumsy, and this has been fixed to a degree in recent releases, but it's probably my biggest complaint with any of their games. I'm sure if this were early 2010 and I were playing this, my complaint would be the same with the wonky controls, but I'd probably think the graphics were better by comparison, but we've all become a bit spoiled. I didn't experience any problems with gameplay whatsoever, and again, the overall feel and fun-factor of the game (this episode, anyway) is huge. Finally, the graphics, even if dated, are lots of fun to look at and very adorable. Everything considered, 7.0/10 - As with a lot of this type, pick up the whole series on a sale or get it as a gift (like I did! :D: ) and you'll have tons of fun with it. I'm likely to play through it again, but replayability is most definitely limited. Good job, as always, Telltale.

The game feels like "Back to the Future" all over again, focused on 1931 as the origin of the time problems, switching through various incarnations of 1986 until the timeline is fixed... in a way. As a bonus, this time around we get to meet young Emmet Brown as well.The game itself could use a few improvements, like merging the 5 parts into just one game or at least sharing the settings between the parts, but the story is pretty much top, and I liked the voice acting too. And heck, the ending... if you liked the movies, the ending is just heavy. If you didn't like the movies then you probably shouldn't play this at all.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Garbage with a side of nostalgiatl;dr - The only value of this game is the desire for Back to the Future feels. I'd grab it on sale merely for this purpose. If you're looking for a remarkable game and have no designs on the movies, don't waste your time.The game opens with familiarity. Doc is testing his time machine then something goes awry. Lo and behold the true story begins. Now you're in the mix and you're in point and click mode, which is the only good part about the controls to this game. Once you have to navigate off screen, you're forced to click, hold and drag to move your character. After my play through, I went back and tried asdw and the arrow keys to move and it worked. Something not explained through regular gameplay, but I digress. The puzzles aren't inherently hard. With enough dialogue and random clicking, you can figure out most of them without a hint. The first episode brings you back to the movies. The second lingers on the same familiarity. By the third episode, I wanted to rush through just to beat the game. The fourth pulls you back in a bit and finally, when you know it's finishing up, the fifth brings you back to feels. Until the end, when it drags feet again, but it's okay because it will wrap up soon, the Delorean will drive into the screen and you will wish you could have it back all over again. The episodes don't link from your gameplay so items you collected do not transfer and neither do your choices. No matter what you name yourself in the first game, your name will be changed in the following.Speaking of episodes, who's idea was it to make you buy a game then repeatedly buy the same game multiple times. Well, it's not an entirely new concept, DLC has been going on for a few years now to rehash old sh**, but for this type of game? I'm not quite sure how much they forced you into spending in the long run, as I bought the game with all the episodes on sale for $4.99, but come on. The listing price was $19.99 and for the life of me I can't possibly think of how it could have been sold for more than $5.00. I spent about 2 hours per episode, with the exception of episode 3 where I walked away to eat and bullsh** for a while bringing my total to around 6 hours. Edna and young doc, separately and together, annoyed the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me. The dialogue wasn't completely terrible, but I'm not sure as to why there were so many Star Wars references thrown in. There were also quite a few glitches in the episodes which made dialogue and entire scenese skip. All in all, I'd say for the $5 it's worth the nostalgia, but the game as a whole is doodoo. Good luck!

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												This was VERY hard for me to say, because there really is a lot to like about this game (I wish Steam would allow us a third option when voting).  The problem is, overall, the pros don't outway the cons.  As far as the GOOD things: the story feels very much like a BTTF movie.  Fans of the movies will no doubt love the fact that some of the original voice actors returned.  The story is good, some of the new characters are interesting, and overall, it's entertaining.  Now, why don't I recommend this game?  If you take off the nostalgic glasses and look at it for what it is, it's not that great.  While I said the storyline was good, it's not GREAT, which is what you would hope for from a game based off the iconic movies (which I myself love).  The plot is very linear (there's not much in the way of choice), and the story doesn't get really interesting until much later in the game.  Also, the setting of a prohibition-era Hill Valley just isn't very captivating.  In addition, the puzzles vary from being either too easy or too vague to get through without hints (the guitar battle is a good example).  Also, and I know this is minor, but the animation is like something out of a kid's cartoon, which contrasts awkwardly with the adult humor and cussing.  There's more I could say, but that would just be rambling.   Overall, if you're a big fan of the movies and can get this game on sale, then YES, buy this game!  But if you're an average Joe looking for a game as good as their later efforts (The Walking Dead; Wolf Among Us), you'll be disappointed.  You'd be better off spending your money on a different title.

												1.21 JIGGAWATTS!  If you're expecting to hear that line somewhere in this game, prepare for disappointment.  While the game starts off with you in the shoes of Marty McFly, you're soon transported to a parallel dimension where a bunch of kids are trying to blow up nuclear reactors as part of an eco-terrorist cell. I thought the writing was okay but there were a few lines like "this guy are sick" that really stood out as evidence that the translators Atlus hired were probably not paid very well.  I recommend playing this game in the original Japanese dub if you can find it.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This is a point and click game based on the Back to the Future movie franchise. It has everything going for it, the music straight from the movie, the nostalgia, the amazing voice cast and the immersion that lets you explore a lot from the movie. This is some good interactive fiction and a point and click was the way to go to tell a story. The only real problem here is the genre just isn't all that fun.The story has you going back in time as Marty McFly from the movies to find Doc Brown and really puts a focus on Doc's youth instead of the movies that put the focus on Marty's family and him saving it. Most of the characters are here from the movie, Marty, his dad George McFly, Doc Brown, Einstein the dog and of course Biff Tannen. It introduces more characters, but they're not the stars. Biff's voice actor could have sounded more like Biff, but Marty's voice actor is fantastic and Doc is played by Christopher Lloyd as always.Since this is a modern point and click game that lets you walk around an area instead of being confined to one screen like the older version of the genre. You'll be able to collect items and use them. That's one of the problems, the tedium of using the items. Going into the item menu, selecting the item, using the item and if you fail then you need to do it all over again. Over and over. , You'll be figuring out what dialog choice you need to make, which character to distract so you can do something with them gone. At least with this and other modern point and click games they accentuate what to click on.I can't say the game is fun and to be honest it feels like a chore to sit through the story. There aren't any crazy moments like in the movie so much as dialog and wandering around. I can't imagine non gamers that are fans of the movie franchise sitting down to enjoy this game and play it all the way through. I can't imagine gamers saying wow that was fun, unless this was the 90s when point and click games were more accepted, before technology left them behind.For the most part, the game is a series of cut scenes to say even the simplest of things. Potentially over and over again. There is some interactivity when you chat with someone, but it feels more like how much flavor dialog do you want to hear? There is always a logical choice with dialog and there are no wrong choices, so much as do you want to listen to all 3 - 5 responses or pick the most logical one to get it over with and progress? There are no real consequences like in Walking Dead where it can change characters and or events. You'll always get through the game. There is no death, there is no failure, there is just pressing on until you figure out what to do next.I've always been a big fan of the Back to the Future movie franchise, and I really enjoyed my first play through of Walking Dead, which is also from Telltale Games, but this game is a chore. The story and the nostalgia just aren't enough to make me want to see what happens next.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Im a huge fan of telltale, and my friend is a huge fan of Back To the Future. How could a Telltale game about Back to the Future go wrong? Easy, by not being a Telltale game to begin with. I dont know if they outsourced this game, or if the art department took the day off and left it to the interns but wow... this game is ugly. The lip syching is awful, and the characters faces lack the complexity to properly emote. But how does it play? Again... nothing like a Telltale game. Instead of a story on rails where you get to occassionally switch tracks to fit your preference, Back to the Future is a point and click puzzle game... do you know how unexciting it is to play a puzzle game coop? The story moves like molassus because your constantly moving back and forth, reading the same dialogue, trying to figure out what item you need, or what line of dialogue will reveal the clue. The pacing was so bad me and my friend quit before chapter 2 was even finished because it was soooo slow.In short, this is a slow, point and click puzzle game, NOT a typical Telltale game... because those are entertaining, this game is not.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												This is my first Telltale game I have played. I just bought the whole collection. Now let me start off with this: I have never been an adventure game fan. This is why I have stayed away from Telltale games. However, hearing just wonderful, awesome, best game ever reviews I finally let my guard down and purchaseed THEM ALL! Here is my verdict so far.TL;DR - Adventure game still aren't for me. Wow, that was a really easy, yet expensive lesson, for me to learn. In a FPS if I shoot someone, they die. If I shoot their arm, they die. If I shoot their face, they die. If I shoot their leg... you get the picture right? Of course you do, you've played FPS b4. Adventure games suffer from constantly having to do exactly what someone decided was the right thing always and conforming your mind to be set completely in track with that person's idea of mindset. Basically, in adventure games, if I shoot your leg first, but the programer thought I would aim for the arm, they do not die. If I shoot the arm, but there was a hint to shoot the face, then leg, then face, then arm, they do not die. You see why I do not like adventure games? I can't just play them. I have to spend hours figuring out every nuance that some other geek decided was the right way. BttF is no different. 1.5 hours in and I'm just clicking on every highlighted item, in a static world, wondering what logic the programer decided would work to make a damn barrel of alchohol fall from a shelf. AND THAT is exactly why I wish I had never bought any Telltale game. Definately not ALL OF THEM! So much buyer's remorse! What have I done?!

Although you can see that Telltale Games put a lot of effort into this project (voices, music, design...), it certainly does not compare to their newer games. There were some episodes where I really had to force myself not to quit because the story was pretty mediocre and the tasks were boring. Episode 3 (Citizen Brown) was probably the best episode of this series.The biggest issue I have with this game are the bugs, particularly in episode 5. Pretty much at the beginning, in the Glass House, I managed to encouter two game-breaking bugs, which meant I had to do everything all over - twice. That sucked... Plus, the German language version has some serious dubbing problems, i.e. sentences get cut off suddenly, and some sentences haven't been translated at all. Is this a big deal? Yes, if you pay 23 bucks, it certainly is. Fans of the franchise, however, might want to take a look at this game, if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												After purchasing the complete collection of Same and Max games on Steam, I had high hopes for Back to the Future: The Game. I love Telltale, I love point-and-click adventures, I LOVE Back to the Future. What could go wrong?Answer: A lot, apparently.As later chapters were released, the somewhat thin layer of polish that came from the first few chapters very quickly peeled away. Events happened in the wrong order, characters would suddenly pop into scenes they weren't in before. Voice acting would randomly cut out in the middle of a line. The crowning achievement was during a car chase scene, when you could clearly see some sort of editor handle bouncing around behind the vehicle.The game ends with the tease of a sequel, and I honestly kind of hope that it doesn't get one.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												Okay, I've seen Back To The Future hundreds of times (I'm not exaggerating, I wish I was). I was thrilled when this game came out and I finally was able to buy it. When we arrive at this point I have to admit that I like almost anything BTTF related, even the animated series. But this game... This game makes me angry. I've played two other games by telltale and I quite love it, but this game is outrageous.There is not difficulty on this, in every location you have normally three/four things to interact with, you don't carry many objects with you (you can count it with your hand's fingers) and any conversation eventually leads with what the developers want to. You can't get lost somewhere because there's so little things to do and so little things to talk about that there is literally NO WAY to miss something. What I hated the most were the conversations where you had three options but the three of them where basically the same. What's the point then?So the interesting thing about this game is not playing it but watching it and see how the story goes and... Nope. The story is just not worth it, really simple and plain, full of plot holes and the graphics don't help. They're good enough to be bad and get you out of focus.The gameplay is quite tedious, if you walk from one point to another in some chapters you will cross with somebody and you'll have to watch that terrible animation with that same face with the nodding that EVERY CHARACTER will do. The movement is not the best thing in the world to be honest.Basically this game consists in clicking two things to see the next animation. Kind of LA Noire but with worse graphics and even worse gameplay.The only good thing I have to say about this is that this game came out 5 years ago. They released after that Jurassic Park and The Walking Dead and they clearly improved so hey, let's just consider it just a big mistake (praised by the critics and the gamers, I STILL DON'T KNOW WHY).My veredict: Sadly disappointing.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Its a point and click adventure game, but the puzzles only come in two flavours, ridiculously easy (Put the key in the lock) to just bizarrely obscure (working out how to get a barrel of booze from one end of the room to the other without interacting with it) so while about 40% of the game can be solved in seconds the other 20% of the game is just half an hour of watching the same cut scenes over and over again till it triggers the next section of game play...the remaining 40%? walking...just slowly or moderately walking back and forth with little to no extras to carry the game along. the Easter eggs are forced and very literal (Any excuse to force the names of the directors of the film can and will be used)The game glitches. Alot...sound randomly drops out or amplifies sometimes the cut scenes will glitch through buildings leaving you watching a black screen while they just talk very very slowly...on at least 3 occassions the game completely bricked and wouldnt let me quit so I had to force my computer off and back on again.the first part came out in 2009 with the rest coming out in 2010...and the graphics...are not great. I wasnt expecting cinematic graphics for a 5-6 year old game...but the graphics are on a par if not marginally better than Late PS2/Very very early PS3 graphics...they all have flappy mouths as well rather than synching the dialogue so sometimes cut scenes just end with a load of flappy heads...I only point out the graphics because the likes of Fallout 3 came out between 2007-2011 and are utterly astounding in terms of quality against this...The only good things I can say about it is the plot itself isnt terrible. Its got quite a back to the future  "feel" but it does come across as boarder fanfic at times (Making up "mary sue" characters and making the heros almost untouchable in terms of having any bad attributes) and that Martys soundalike is really quite good...Doc sounds good...everyone else sounds iffy...I Payed a £5 for all 5 parts of the game during the summer sale and for a pound a part I'd say it was alright...but avoid paying full price at all costs...Its really not worth it. 4/10

number of helpful: 13 of 35 people (37%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Back to the Future: The Game consists of five episodes which are a sequel to the movie trilogy.Doc Brown the inventor of the time machine has gone back to the '30s and he will die via mob justice. Now its up to you to change his fate, but as we learned from the movies, screwing with the past mucks up the future. The goal is to make sure the Hill Valley of 1986 is just how Marty left it. Telltale fail miserably at making their own circa 1931 Hill Valley anything more than a studio lot full of comedy gangsters.The gameplay is traditional adventure stuff. You walk around as Marty, talk to citizens and use items to solve puzzles. Unfortunately the puzzles are very easy, uninspired and boring.The characters are just as bland, also most of the characters are cardboard nobodies. At least, in some cases, the acting is good. On the most basic level, the actors sound like the original characters.The graphics do not render smoothly and the worst part is that these tech problems distract from the cinematic gameplay.The sounds of the game are pretty decent. Music is mostly in the background and not too distracting and actual sound effects also take a backseat in favour of the voice acting. The voice acting is definitely the best part in the game. If you are a big fan of the movies, then you could think about getting Back to the Fute: The Game. However, if the franchise does not really appeal to you, then this game may not be in your interest because the game practically relies on the player knowing the characters and the setting.Sound 7/10Graphics 6/10Gameplay 3/10Atmosphere 3/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

												This game is the digital version of taking pure nostalgia and injecting it in your arm. If you're at all a fan of the movies, you can't miss out on this experience.

Posted: August 1, 2013
												This was a game I have to admit I REALLY enjoyed. It has everything a graphic adventure should have - the freedom and choice to turn the plot around a little (although it is fairly linear) and comedy. There are so many points within this that will literally make you laugh out loud, and other points where you'll fear for the well-being of the characters.Thankfully, for those like me who struggle occasionally with some of the plot devices, there are hints that will help! Sometimes this can be used to clear up a miscommunication between you and the game, or in other times, to check that you're doing the right thing.It also keeps an up-to-date summary of the story so far, so when you feel like you want to resume playing after an extended break, there is the ability to remind yourself of what's already happened.I recommend this game to anyone who loves puzzles, has a good sense of humour and those that want a game filled with nostalgia to remind them what the good ol' days were like (even though I wasn't born close to them!)

Posted: May 24, 2014
												Working with such compelling proprietary content, Telltale, the reigning champions of turning licenced properties into enjoyable adventure games, could only do so wrong.  And they almost do that wrong, but they salvage a playable experience through a fun story, strong voice acting and writing, and impeccable faithfulness to the tone and spirit of the beloved Back to the Future franchise.To stress, the gameplay itself is not the draw.  Puzzles act as minor speedbumps on the way to advancement of the story and dialogue.  The control scheme, identical to that of earlier Wallace and Gromit and Monkey Island offerings, clearly favors a console/controller over a mouse/keyboard setup.  The bulk of content is a bit too dialogue heavy which eventually causes the games to drag.   Unlike the aforementioned W&G and MI series that could rely heavily on absurdism humor in the dialogue, Back to the Future conversations are generally coherent --though certainly funny in their own way .  So a surfeit of quality writing and acting --especially by Christopher Lloyd! -- does truly feel like too much.Nonetheless, the game gets a thumbs up, albeit a very tepid one.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												Back to the Future: The Game is now over 5 years old. It was released in conjunction with the 25th anniversary of the first film. Now that the 30th anniversary is behind us, and 2015 came and left, can this game survive on its own merits?As a "Back to the Future" game it hits all the right notes. References to the films aren't clustered too close together and surprise you when you least expect them. It feels more like "Back to the Future" than any other game that shared that title before. The characters are familiar and their portrayal in this game feels very authentic. In many ways this game feels like a genuine piece of the film's legacy that had been lost to the ages. As a point and click adventure game it is a bit too simple. The puzzles seemed too easy at times and there were very few times when I needed to consult the in game hint box. Every puzzle has an obvious solution and the game's objective reminders guarantees that the player doesn't get too far off the path.Simple though it is the game is fun and I would gladly reccommend it to any fan of the series.

Posted: January 14, 2011
												Telltale are improving at their adventure games. They're trying different things (like conversations while you're walking through a large area and cool action sequences but in the adventure game mould...) but still fall down on old issues. Lip-synch is a little off, environments are a little empty, sounds are sometimes missing, the engine is slow, and there are bits where you wish they spent an extra week or so polishing because the hasty production shows. But there is a lotta love in this game. Lots of call-backs to the movies abound. The music and voice acting is spot-on and they totally nailed the DeLorean. Heck, they even got real science-y words in there. I'm interested to see what they do in future episodes.

												It's Back! After 20 years of waiting we finally have something worth of being called a "Sequel" To the movie trillagy that made the late 80s and early 90s awesome! Posted: May 24, 2014
												Working with such compelling proprietary content, Telltale, the reigning champions of turning licenced properties into enjoyable adventure games, could only do so wrong.  And they almost do that wrong, but they salvage a playable experience through a fun story, strong voice acting and writing, and impeccable faithfulness to the tone and spirit of the beloved Back to the Future franchise.To stress, the gameplay itself is not the draw.  Puzzles act as minor speedbumps on the way to advancement of the story and dialogue.  The control scheme, identical to that of earlier Wallace and Gromit and Monkey Island offerings, clearly favors a console/controller over a mouse/keyboard setup.  The bulk of content is a bit too dialogue heavy which eventually causes the games to drag.   Unlike the aforementioned W&G and MI series that could rely heavily on absurdism humor in the dialogue, Back to the Future conversations are generally coherent --though certainly funny in their own way .  So a surfeit of quality writing and acting --especially by Christopher Lloyd! -- does truly feel like too much.Nonetheless, the game gets a thumbs up, albeit a very tepid one.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Very few movie liscense games are good. Even fewer are good after it's been years since the release of the movie. This Game is one of the few good ones. By no means is this the best movie liscensed game but in my honest opinion it still has the ability to stand on it's own. Back to the Future is set after the events of the last film in the franchise and as such there are plenty of references to the original movies. The writing still has charm, yet at certain points the game has a different feel to the story of the films, even if it is the same story line. The sound is somewhat subpar in certain places during the game, but at the very least the original soundtrack returns. At times thought, I felt as though I was playing a game for the 6th generation consoles (wii, ps2, xbox). Indeed, the graphics don't have the best polish however if you don't mind the cartoony stylization of the game it shouldn't bother anyone. The gameplay is your average point and click adventure which works in the games favor because making a fps or third person shooter out of this style of game would have been horendous Overall, as a story that expands the lore of the movies this game is pretty great, but stand alone it just okay. I'd suggest that mainly fans of the franchise play this game.

												As a huge fan of the Back to the Future movie and a..slight fan of point and click adventure games, I picked this up, and I wasn't disapointed. With the original writers of the series on the team, the game 100% fits in to the BTTF canon set after the third film with many little subtle nods to things in the trilogy, and Chris Lloyd  the original doc reprises his role in voice form.Very funny and surprisingly well written, I would say the only downside is it's very easy for a TellTale point and click, you won't get stuck really, but this is more so aimed at the fans, good at games or not. So if you liked BTTF and its characters, you shant be disapointed~

Posted: January 29, 2016
												   I've just finished episode 5 and I can say that I really enjoyed this game.   First off, lets keep in mind that it's clear that the Telltale formula wasn't fully developed here. There's no moral dilemmas because there's no choices to be made in this game. It's not a branched narrative.   The graphics aren't 2016 worthy and it crashes a lot. BUT there's an amazing cinematic feel to every episode.   It's extremely difficult, even impossible to play without using the hints that are given to you. You will be stuck in a puzzle for a long time because most puzzles make no sense.    The most important aspect is obviously the story itself. I'm not a Back to the Future fan but I really enjoyed seeing all these characters that we got to meet on the big screen.    It's a fun game that I don't regret playing.

Posted: April 18, 2016
												Video Review (for those who don't like reading): 


YouTube™ Video: LittleZbot Reviews: Back To The Future: The Game (Spoiler Free) 

			Views: 41		

			What? LittleZbot made something serious for once? What kind of alternate universe is this? We reviewed this as filler content for next week, but we did enjoy making this, so we might do more. Might.		

Back to the Future: The Game is a puzzle-adventure game taking inspiration from point-and-click titles. You click on various items to interact with them or investigate them, and use the items and your surroundings to solve puzzles that advance the story. Does it work? Well, yes and no. When it comes to video games, there’s an age-old question: Gameplay or Story: which is more important? Well, if you’ve ever been on the fence about this question, then Back to the Future: The Game will solve it for you in the first half an hour.First, the story is astounding. It manages to fully capture all the magic and feel of the original movies while still being its own thing. After playing through the whole game, I, and I’d say most other people who played it, felt the story alone made it worthy to bear the title of Back to the Future Part IV. Considering that it was a collaboration from the people at Telltale Games, the people behind Tales from the Borderlands, and the guys who made the original three movies, and the story writer for this game happens to be the very same person who wrote the original three movies, I’m not all that surprised, though I am impressed that they managed to capture the same magic of the original movies more than twenty-five years after they released. The voice work is fantastic all-around, unsurprising since they got some of the original actors to play their parts, and every new character feels like they always belonged in the Back to the Future universe. For the most part, the dialog is well-written, the graphics are surprisingly fitting and work well, and the music is…directly stolen from the movies. Of course, the soundtrack of the movies is fantastic, so that’s not necessarily a bad thing. In addition, the puzzles are clever without being completely unfair. My favorite part of the game was during the last episode, where you have to jog somebody’s memory through giving their brain certain stimulations to represent what happened in the past. A mop head on a cactus makes a grandpa, a sign on an outhouse makes a saloon, and so on. I only ever had to look up the solution to one puzzle in the very first episode, and that ended up only being because my controller didn’t recognize a required object as an item.And that’s where we get into what’s wrong with the game. After all, when you get a bunch of movie producers to make a video game, you can expect the story and dialog to be good, but the game itself? Not so much. Where should I start? Well, the camera is among the worst I‘ve ever seen, being annoyingly hard to control, and since most of the time you never need to manipulate it, you end up forgetting you can entirely, which makes parts of the game later on when you do need to manipulate it very confusing. It also picks these strange moments to suddenly switch perspectives, which throw you off whenever you’re trying to go somewhere across town. There are invisible walls everywhere, giving you a sort of fake-3D experience, but then often you can move around freely, and you just can’t tell the difference. Despite Hill Valley feeling so big, I feel just so constricted because of this. Plus, Marty is so slow! Even when he’s running, which, if you’re smart, he’ll always be, it still feels like it takes forever to get anywhere. All three of these aspects combined makes traversing the world around you a chore. That’s not mention the terrible controls. Here’s the thing: you’ll spend half of your time clicking, and the other half walking. Initially, it seems that a controller is the best option for both of these, as one of the control sticks can be used to skip from one clickable item onscreen to another with ease, and the other can be used to walk freely, whereas you have to drag the mouse a couple of inches away from Marty in whatever direction you want to go if you want to use the mouse. However, as I mentioned earlier, sometimes your controller will skip right over items, because it doesn’t recognize them, and very often, those items are required to solve a puzzle in the game. So you end up constantly switching between two means of controlling, using the controller to move and the mouse to click, and, trust me, it gets REALLY annoying. Also, if you hold down either the mouse or the button for more than a half a second during dialog, it sometimes acts like you clicked twice, and skips important pieces of dialog. Also, just a tip: in the first episode, a reporter will ask Marty for his name. Just tell her it’s Harry Callahan, because no matter what, everyone is going to refer to him as that.Is playing the game a chore? Not necessarily. The music and characters keep the atmosphere up, the puzzles are fairly good, and the story makes you want to keep going. It’s more of a whether or not the story is worth drudging through the terrible camera and controls. I’ll tell you this; if Chuggaconroy ever made a let’s play of this game, I’d recommend watching it well over playing the game yourself. However, when you look at the other Steam reviews for the game, you’ll see that the vast majority are positive, and most of the negative ones simply say that the game is “meh,” and the story and gameplay cancel each other out. Many of the positive reviews say that the story is what makes the game worth playing. And here’s the thing: I think they’re right. The game is going to be really annoying to play through due to the controls, but the feeling you’ll get when you solve a puzzle is never to be underestimated, and every resulting cutscene is a reward in and of itself. I certainly wouldn’t recommend watching a walkthrough over playing it, but if you have a character of interesting personality doing a let’s play, you might want to stick to that. Still, the story, music, dialog, characters, and perfect capturing of the feel of the movies makes this game more than worth the while. On the gameinformer scale of 1-10, with 7 being average, 10 being perfection, and 1 being the Ouya controller, I’d give this game a 4 for gameplay and 9 for story, which rounds off to 6.5, and I‘ll bring it up to a 7 just so I can recommend it officially.Back to the Future: The Game, gets a 7 out of 10.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Back to the Future: The Game does a stunning job of recapturing the feel and flavor of the film trilogy that inspired it. Despite lacking some of the functionality Telltale's become known for in later games, especially regards to consequence, BttF is a solid adventure experience through and through with only a few bits I found frustrating. Set (initially) in Prohibition-era Hill Valley, the bulk of Back to the Future: The Game is an exploration of Doc Brown's past, and how he became the eccentric genius scientist we know him as in the movies. After tracking down Doc following a journey gone a bit awry, Marty McFly's stuck juggling multiple eras of Doc and eventually having to deal with a much different Doc than he's used to. The consequences of minor changes are even more evident this time around than they were in the films, though the quests to fix those changes show a wide variety of Hill Valleys that were and could have been.First things first, I need to commend all the performers they got to fill the various roles. Marty McFly's voice actor is a dead ringer for 80's-era Michael J. Fox, and the rest of the familiar cast is well-represented. New characters abound without overwhelming familiar faces, and are all established firmly enough that you care about them, be it out of love or of loathing. It's nice that the game manages to give Marty's history some time in the spotlight as well, despite all the focus on Doc.Progress in the game is based primarily on conversation, working your way through options to figure out what's going on, what to do next, and how to get people to do what you need. There are several points where this can get tedious and/or unclear as to how to proceed, but those bits are few and far between, especially as you get into the later episodes. There's a bit of item collection and use, but it takes a back seat to the dialogue trees, which makes for a great showcase of Telltale's writing skill. Action sequences pop up from time to time as well, which add to the cinematic feel of the game but are also the weakest, gameplay-wise. Several times, I found myself going in circles trying to figure out how to finish an action sequence, only to find I was missing a single, relatively tiny (visually and figuratively) piece of the puzzle. I guess my best advice for these bits is to look up. Always look up.Other than that, Back to the Future: The Game is absolutely worth your time. A fitting tribute to the films, these five episodes could easily be considered canon if they aren't already.

Posted: January 18, 2016
I only recommend this game on sale to fans of the BTTF movies. It is a a bare bones point & click linear adventure game with many mildly infuriating components, but is a faithful 5 episode sequel to the BTTF movies.  You play as Marty McFly in 1985 which starts with an homage to the first movie, but takes place after the 3 movies.Cons::One track linear story: Your actions don't affect what happens in the story other than progressing it linearly and definitely do not carry over between episodes.  Choose Your Own Adventure books offer more choice.Dialog selection not consistent with voice acting: On a regular basis I select a dialog choice, and Marty says something that differs in tone and/or content from what I selected, as if voice script was rewritten after the dialog UI was setup.Movement limited between areas: In 1st episode movement is limited from the front of the courthouse to either side of the courthouse.Graphics same as lowest common ported denominator: Aside from antialiasing, I may as well have run the game on a Nintendo Wii.  Low poly counts on characters is a bad choice for such a character & dialog driven game.Episodes have separate settings and launchers: Ever change any of the game settings? Be prepared to change them for each new episode that you launch.  There is no central UI for accessing each of the episodes.Pros::Story and atmosphere: This is a story that fits the franchise well and has a number of nuanced details that fans will appreciate.Voice acting: Telltale found an impressive Fox soundalike actor and Christopher Lloyd's return is great, along with decent supporting voice acting.Hint system: Great for casual players.
