Posted: November 2, 2015
												This game is a must have for fans of the movie trilogy and just fans of these types of point and click games in general. It has quite a few flaws that i will detail below, but the good triumphs over the bad if the game is on sale. Good aspects:Detailed and well thought out story that links all five episodes together - Each story has logical and believable writing and execution in relation to the movies. The motives of the characters is similar to that of what was in the movies and it is told well enough.Great voice acting/dialogue/characters - the person portraying Marty sounds so similar to Mr. Fox in the movies that i kept on actually believing that it really was him doing his best vocal impression of himself at that young age. Christopher Lloyd was also a delight to listen to. As were the other lead characters for the most part. Nostalgia - The game nails it when it comes to bringing memories back from the movies,  referencing certain aspects of the three movies and just celebrating the most memorable lines, moments and scenes in the movie trilogy without over doing it. Bad aspects:Presentation/animation - The character renders and overall presentation is quite bad in comparison to other games that celebrate famous movies (such as Ghostbusters: The Video Game, which came out a year earlier and which looked well detailed and thorogh in its visual appearance snd actually lets you roam around freely with very few issues) Roaming around in the Hill Valley in this game can seem like somewhat of a chore at times with the limitations on where you can walk and the camera angles nearly impossoble to manouvere. That doesn't change whether you use the keyboard controls or your mouse. The design of Hill Valley looks decent enough, but the whole presentation and animations of the chatacters could have been way better if the right time and money was invested. Still, it was still ok and not game breaking for me. Graphically, the game doesn't look as if it reaches its potential.Choice-based gameplay being limited - The choices that they let your character make are very limiting and don't really add much to your path in the story because whichever options you pick, your character will ultimately go always go in the same path. That is because with the options they provide you during interaction with various characters, you almost always have to pick all of them to move forward in the story. For example, playing as Marty, as you're interacting with Doc Brown you need to find out a specific piece of information and are given four or more choices of questions or phrases you can ask/provide, but you have to ask pretty much all of them to get to where you need to so there isn't really a huge amount of choice involved in actuality.Overall, it is a very good game for what it is that would be most enjoyed if you're a fan of the movie series that could have been amazing if a little more time and money were invested into this. Probably not worth it for the full price, but is great value when on sale.However, if they released a sequel to this (whether in episodic format or otherwise), then i would definitely buy it especially if they fixed the flaws that were in this game.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												Having never seen the 'Back to the Future' movie franchise, I was unsure what to expect with this outing from Telltale. However, what "Back to the Future: The Game" delivers is a charming, humorous, and at times, gripping point & click adventure. If you have seen the original movies, then I'm sure the added references and familiar characters will be a bonus. Indeed, some of the original cast provide the voices for the characters, to add further authenticity. The game sees the player take on the role of the movies' protaganist, Marty McFly, as he and the eccentric, 'Doc' Brown experience misadventures in Marty's home town of Hill Valley, in different times and time-lines. The gameplay centres on solving multiple 'puzzles', by using the environment, collected items, and dialogue with a variety of in-game characters to progress the story. If you are a fan of Telltale's most recent 'Monkey Island' release, then you'll certainly be at home. If you are a fan of the movie franchise linked to the game, which is set following the events of the third movie, incidentally, then I can only assume that with excellent voice-acting delivery from some of the movies' original cast at the very least, you will consider this game a welcome addition to the franchise.

												I really enjoy playing this game.  If you're a fan of Back to the Future, you will love it.  They stay true to the characters and fit the plot around the films. Posted: February 26, 2015
												Review of "Episode 1: It's About Time"Pro: Keeps with the spirit of the BttF trilogy The fourth instalment you always wanted Amusing scenarios Christopher Lloyd Joypad supportCon: Controls are a teeny bit clunky Much clunkier when using joypad Intense sound track is a bit much when you're stuck on a puzzle More an Interactive Fiction than a Game as such (could be a pro as well!)"You built a time machine out of a De Lorean??" The conversation between Marty McFly and 'Doc' Brown seems very familiar but something isn't quite right. And it ends up with our time travelling heroes getting stuck in Prohibition Era Hill Valley. Along the way they meet Marty's grandfather Arty, Principal Strickland's aunt, and a 17 year old Emmett Brown. The game is presented with lovely looking 3D cartoon graphics and a voice cast including Christopher Lloyd reprising his role as Doc Brown. The actor playing Marty totally nails the teenage Michael J. Fox voice too! The story is supervised by Bob Gale who co-wrote the films with Bob Zemeckis and, you know, it really does come off in the spirit of the films. (If perhaps on the fan service side of things.)The game plays out like most point-and-click adventure games. You move Marty around the environment and interact with specific elements or characters to move the story along. The philosophy for the game seems to be that the story is important above everything. In this regard, the puzzles are never overly difficult or distracting from the story. The player is never penalised for their actions which means you are free to go through all the character responses which are often amusing. To this end, Back to the Future: The Game ends up being a bit more interactive fiction than a game as such. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. The story and acting are engaging and you find that you want to move along as well.Playing the game isn't very different to many adventure games. I've always found the genre a bit clunky to move around in and while the developers at Telltale Games add a bit of polish to make the controls a bit forgiving, I find it's really an endemic fault of the genre. I was extremely pleased to find that there was gamepad support for the game and I could take advantage of Big Picture Mode. The gamepad is usable, and I used it for about half of the game, but it is also quite clunky to use.Probably the only thing that really bothered me about the game were the few intense scenes where the music swells up and scene gets busy. There is a sense of urgency in the scenario but because the adventure game is to some degree turn based it's difficult to satisfy that urgency. It becomes a little frustrating and you kind of want to turn all the sound off so you can concentrate on the puzzle you're supposed to be solving.Otherwise Back to the Future: The Game, Episode One is a delightful little game and I look forward to playing the subsequent instalments.

Posted: June 12, 2015
Story: Without running into spoiler land I will give you a brief idea of how this story goes. It takes place seven months after the end of the trilogy. This plays into what happens with life after the last movie. Marty is home and Doc is still in the past. Marty, sad at the loss of his friend to time is suddenly interuppted when the DeLorean suddenly appears and Marty is thrust into another adventure.Appearance: As with many Telltale games this has a cartoon like design. The design is initially off putting with how the movies appear but in no time the art style grows on you. The atmosphere is perfect and captures not only the feel but the over themes of the BTTF movies. This is a perfect continuation.Gameplay: This is a standard point and click adventure. It has a pretty standard 90's P&C feel to it to a fault. It has many of the issues that plagued those games. Issues getting characters to move properly or collision detection. Over all the game feels well done and is really a joy to play.Achievements: The only achievement this game came with is having a wonderful time playing the game. The story is reward enough for that.Bottom Line: This game is such a great deal of fun I regret not playing it sooner. Not only is it the perfect game for a BTTF fan but its a great point and click adventure. Each episode will run you about 2 hours of gameplay for a total 10 hours of gameplay. I picked this up when it was on sale and I would even go so far as to recommend that its even worth the full price. Pick this up at your next chance and give it a go.

												Great Scott! This game is amazing: great story, true to movies, amazing art direction, it has well written characters, a surpisingly intriguing antagonist and amazing voice-work. The story continues right where Back To The Future part 3 ends, with new adventures and new time periods that neatly fold into a great over-arching story. Posted: January 22, 2015
												Telltale Games one of their first finest work!It might not be Telltale Games first developed title but, I was pleasantly surprised by this "Back to the Future: The Game" episodic series. It follows the adventures of the good ol' Doc Emmett Brown and his good friend, Marty McFly. It's not truly mandatory to have seen the movies BUT, it really helps to have background information of the movies. To put it short, this adventure game has a new story set after BttF Part 3 movie (it could be seen as a BttF Part 4). It ends with a possibility for more content so whether or not it becomes another episodic season or a new movie, but this season/series ended in 2011 so not sure if a sequel is likely... we shall see...The episodic format takes you about 3 to 4 hours for each episode to complete. If you skip conversations and if you use or not, the hint system, the game can be shorter or longer.PROS:+Funny, goofy... just like the movies!+Familiar setting with the visuals, voice cast, music.+Interesting story. It could almost be interpreted as Back to the Future: Part 4.+Hints mechanic to help you if you are being stuck.+Stong voice acting skills of the actors.+Christopher Lloyd voice acting his movie character, Doc Brown. Micheal J. Fox appeared for the final episode!CONS:-Filler between episodes: Seems to drag between later episodes.-Technical issues: Each time I started a new episode, the game kept crashing until a game restart and then another restart once the settings were changed.-Puzzles are somewhat easy but the HUD elements makes it hard at times to see where you have to click and is bothersome.OVERALL:A good adventure game. Not the best of Telltale Games and you cannot compare this to their "The Walking Dead" masterpiece series but I quite enjoyed this Back to the Future: The Game series.RECOMMENDATION:If you liked BttF movies and you like point & click adventure, goofy-funny games, you should really enjoy this BttF: The Game. You may want to wait for a sale though... as I did!Just remember... it is not mandatory to have seen the movies BUT it really helps that you do! I watched the three movies just before starting this game and let me tell you that I would have been lost since it was so long ago! At least, read the synopsis of the movies before playing this game or you may feel lost here and there!RATING:7.0 / 10

Posted: July 6, 2011
												If you're a fan of the movie, you're going to love this.Back to the Future the game is everything that you hope it to be and a little bit more. Learning more about the little town of Hill Valley and the pasts, and futures, of the characters fans have come to love. Like all Telltale games you'll find yourself asking a lot of questions, all of which get answered in a timely fashion (pun intended). The delivery of the story is executed extraordinarily well, making you feel something a little different with each episode and leaving you on enough of a cliff hanger that will only make you want to play the next. I guarantee the whole experience will leave you feeling nostalgic and thoroughly satisfied. I recommend this to anyone who is a fan of Back to the Future. Without question, it is a game that every fan should play. If you've never seen the movie, now is the time to become a fan, so that you can play this well developed and charming game. I rate it a 9.6 out of 10.

												I really enjoy playing this game.  If you're a fan of Back to the Future, you will love it.  They stay true to the characters and fit the plot around the films.  The game is set after the third film and has a fantastic plotline which jumps between 1985 an 1931 - you play as Marty McFly trying to stop Doc from dying in the 1930s, but then obviously it gets more complicated (that's timetravel for you!)One thing to keep in mind is that you have basically no control over anything, unlike Telltale's later games like Walking Dead and TWAU.  Every choice you make is either meaningless, or a filler answer until you reach the one you need.  But that is my only critisism of the game, and apart from that, I loved everything!I would highly recommend this game for anybody who likes story-rich games, or just anybody who likes Back to the Future. Posted: December 27, 2014
												As the millennial age broadened gaming to a wider audience, more and more big franchises from the 80's and early 90's began to adapt themselves in bigger budgeted games.  When news of a Back to the Future adventure game created by Telltale surfaced, there was an explosion of fan interest into how it would turn out. They were not disappointed.The story takes place after the movie. Marty goes back in time to rescue Doc Brown, who landed himself in jail in 1931. During this inital event, he comes across many past characters of Hill Valley, including a young Doc Brown. As the story progesses, both Marty and Doc travel back and forth through time to fix an even greater mess on the timeline then the one in Back to the Future II. Needless to say, it gets heavy.Very few of the movie's original cast returns, which is a shame. While the voice actors perform wonderfully, it is obvious that they are filling in for who didn't return. The exception is the voice actor for Marty, who is so convincing that many fans won't notice if not told out-right. It's his performance that make this game feel like a direct continuation of the movie.The game isn't as polished or long as more recent Telltale Games such as The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us, so adventure game fans won't find much challenge. There is, however, just enough content to satisfy any fan of the series and is very well worth a purchase.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												If you are a fan of the BTTF trilogy then you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying this game. It is obviously created with a lot of love and zeal for the series and all of the episodes were thoroughly enjoyable to the point where I did not want them to end. Took 2 hours to complete each episode so you can think of them as 5 brand new plots to add to the original three and they interweave fantastically as well as exploring some interesting new concepts for Marty and Doc to explore, Overall I would give the series as a whole a solid 9.5/10 for a fan of BTTF as it really captures the spirit of the films and has a wonderful art style whilst remaining really undemanding on the hardware seeing as how my laptop could run it at 4k with no dips from 60fps.

Posted: February 26, 2015
												Review of "Episode 1: It's About Time"Pro: Keeps with the spirit of the BttF trilogy The fourth instalment you always wanted Amusing scenarios Christopher Lloyd Joypad supportCon: Controls are a teeny bit clunky Much clunkier when using joypad Intense sound track is a bit much when you're stuck on a puzzle More an Interactive Fiction than a Game as such (could be a pro as well!)"You built a time machine out of a De Lorean??" The conversation between Marty McFly and 'Doc' Brown seems very familiar but something isn't quite right. And it ends up with our time travelling heroes getting stuck in Prohibition Era Hill Valley. Along the way they meet Marty's grandfather Arty, Principal Strickland's aunt, and a 17 year old Emmett Brown. The game is presented with lovely looking 3D cartoon graphics and a voice cast including Christopher Lloyd reprising his role as Doc Brown. The actor playing Marty totally nails the teenage Michael J. Fox voice too! The story is supervised by Bob Gale who co-wrote the films with Bob Zemeckis and, you know, it really does come off in the spirit of the films. (If perhaps on the fan service side of things.)The game plays out like most point-and-click adventure games. You move Marty around the environment and interact with specific elements or characters to move the story along. The philosophy for the game seems to be that the story is important above everything. In this regard, the puzzles are never overly difficult or distracting from the story. The player is never penalised for their actions which means you are free to go through all the character responses which are often amusing. To this end, Back to the Future: The Game ends up being a bit more interactive fiction than a game as such. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. The story and acting are engaging and you find that you want to move along as well.Playing the game isn't very different to many adventure games. I've always found the genre a bit clunky to move around in and while the developers at Telltale Games add a bit of polish to make the controls a bit forgiving, I find it's really an endemic fault of the genre. I was extremely pleased to find that there was gamepad support for the game and I could take advantage of Big Picture Mode. The gamepad is usable, and I used it for about half of the game, but it is also quite clunky to use.Probably the only thing that really bothered me about the game were the few intense scenes where the music swells up and scene gets busy. There is a sense of urgency in the scenario but because the adventure game is to some degree turn based it's difficult to satisfy that urgency. It becomes a little frustrating and you kind of want to turn all the sound off so you can concentrate on the puzzle you're supposed to be solving.Otherwise Back to the Future: The Game, Episode One is a delightful little game and I look forward to playing the subsequent instalments.

												Before Telltale games really 'got Adventure Games right for the modern age' with The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us there was this.A funny, easy collection of warped-logic puzzles along with a new setting, plenty of voice talent from Christopher Lloyd, cameo from Michael J Fox, and the writing talent of Bob Gale it's an ideal extension of the original film trilogy that deserves more promotion than it got.Although it may have worked better to be dragged along for the ride as a standalone animated film this title is entertaining enough to be worth the couple of dollars asked for it - even if the linear chapters don't leave you on the edge of your seat.Is it well packaged? Not exactly. Is it perfect? I wouldn't say that. Is it recommended? Absolutely.

Posted: November 22, 2011
												With Telltale's impending release of their new Jurassic Park game, I couldn't help but debate if it would be a worthwhile purchase. Trying to grasp a better understanding of how their new product "feels", I thought it best to extrapolate from older games in their library and this is where Back to the Future: The Game comes in.As the first Telltale game I've ever beaten in its entirety, the best way to describe my feelings after the long journey is a simple, "satisfied". Far away is this game from horrible, but neither is it groundbreaking.As can be inferred by the developer's name, Telltale's work heavily centers on telling a story. They undeniably did a fantastic job with the plot. Prior to playing this, I watched all three (excellent) movies, hoping that the game might reward me for it. And it did. There are plenty references sprinkled throughout, enough to make any fan happy and prove its faithfulness to its predecessors.Grade: (Continued in Episode 2's recommendation)

												I bought this a while ago and now I took the time to play it. This is great stuff! If you like the original movies, you are at the right spot and will love all the references and a continued story. The graphics are fun and the motion capture is so well done that it really catches all the details you know from the original characters. The voice acting is simply awsome (sogar auf Deutsch wurden die Originalstimmen benutzt!) and during the cut scenes I sometimes forgot for a few moments that this is just a game and not an animated movie.If you don't know the movies, sometimes it is probably difficult to keep up, but still a fun game!The puzzles are well balanced and usually work without using the hint system. I would call this intermediate complexity.Recommendation? YES YES YES!!!

Posted: August 29, 2014
												suprisingly goodi half heartedly installed this game expecting the usual slow nice gameplay of point and click adventure games, with the usual frustrations. but this was different;1-the graphics exceeded my expectations, they're really good, beyond what i see from similar games2-the hinting system is a perfect balance between not spoiling the game and not having you look up walkthroughs online every few minutes(ahem, sam and max). you can have a general hint, then a heavy hint, then it tells you what to do(all accesed manually)3-the gameplay is fairly linear if you want to finish quickly, but offers a lot of exploration if you want to go around.4-character design is unique and spectacular, they are rememberable and believable.5-it's a classic, i didn't watch the original movie, which is a historical landmark in movies.3-the story is actually very very well written, it will captivate you, which is why;I highly reccomend you play the episodes in seccession, it's hard to pick up from where you last left off if it was a long time ago.

Posted: September 3, 2016
												A surprisingly fun game, even though I'm not the biggest fan of point-and-click adventure games. The plot is silly at times, but fun nonetheless, and the characters are interesting.I felt a little confined as all five games mostly revolve around one square in town in different timelines and there wasn't that many secondary interactive elements, plus you aren't given any real choices. However, the dialogs are complex enough and puzzles are diverse enough to keep you interested.From the technical point of view, it's mediocre. Voice acting is good, graphics and animation are outdated, camera control is terrible. I mean, it'll easily win the contest for the most messed up camera - you'll find camera switching between three views from completely different directions when you move mouse cursor and the main character looks in different directions. Controller is pretty much unusable as it's close to impossible to click precisely.Overall, if you're a fan of Back to the Future even in a slightest, you don't want to miss the game, but it does have some rough edges.

Posted: April 19
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review ANOTHER DISCLAIMER: Back to the Future: The Game has five episodes which are split seperately and are downloaded one by one, thus reviews are more or less the same as the gameplay mechanics are basically the same in all five episodes. So please think before commenting about the similarity in the reviews Back to the Future: The Game is an episodic adventure game with five episodes, developed and published by Telltale Games, the same people behind other such great adventure games as The Wolf Among Us and Game of Thrones. The game is based on the film series of the same nameAlthough the game does not follow the same exact storyline as the first film, it follows the same universe as Back to the Future follows only seeing it in a different point of viewAs mentioned previously, the game is split up into five episodes. The game works as a normal television series. Each length of an episode is roughly one hour longThe gameplay is very simple, you move around, selecting stuff and talking to people and using button prompts when told to. Choices don't really matter as to other Telltale GamesThe game's graphics are okay for the most part however there are some ugly texture work here and there. The sound and music options also vary in quality. Sometimes the sound quality is really good and sometimes the sound quality is bad. I have encountered numerous amounts of glitches which seems as if Telltale Games never got round to fixing them, too many to mention in this reviewTelltale's Back to the Future: The Game pays a good homage to the Back to the Future film series and is definitely better than Jurassic Park: The Game which is another Universal Pictures license RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: December 22, 2014
												I really enjoy playing this game.  If you're a fan of Back to the Future, you will love it.  They stay true to the characters and fit the plot around the films.  The game is set after the third film and has a fantastic plotline which jumps between 1985 an 1931 - you play as Marty McFly trying to stop Doc from dying in the 1930s, but then obviously it gets more complicated (that's timetravel for you!)One thing to keep in mind is that you have basically no control over anything, unlike Telltale's later games like Walking Dead and TWAU.  Every choice you make is either meaningless, or a filler answer until you reach the one you need.  But that is my only critisism of the game, and apart from that, I loved everything!I would highly recommend this game for anybody who likes story-rich games, or just anybody who likes Back to the Future.  It's a lot of fun, a wonderful story, and an all round enjoyable game to play!  I really hope they make a second series at some point!

Posted: December 27, 2014
												As the millennial age broadened gaming to a wider audience, more and more big franchises from the 80's and early 90's began to adapt themselves in bigger budgeted games.  When news of a Back to the Future adventure game created by Telltale surfaced, there was an explosion of fan interest into how it would turn out. They were not disappointed.The story takes place after the movie. Marty goes back in time to rescue Doc Brown, who landed himself in jail in 1931. During this inital event, he comes across many past characters of Hill Valley, including a young Doc Brown. As the story progesses, both Marty and Doc travel back and forth through time to fix an even greater mess on the timeline then the one in Back to the Future II. Needless to say, it gets heavy.Very few of the movie's original cast returns, which is a shame. While the voice actors perform wonderfully, it is obvious that they are filling in for who didn't return. The exception is the voice actor for Marty, who is so convincing that many fans won't notice if not told out-right. It's his performance that make this game feel like a direct continuation of the movie.The game isn't as polished or long as more recent Telltale Games such as The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us, so adventure game fans won't find much challenge. There is, however, just enough content to satisfy any fan of the series and is very well worth a purchase.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Back to the Future: The Game does a stunning job of recapturing the feel and flavor of the film trilogy that inspired it. Despite lacking some of the functionality Telltale's become known for in later games, especially regards to consequence, BttF is a solid adventure experience through and through with only a few bits I found frustrating. Set (initially) in Prohibition-era Hill Valley, the bulk of Back to the Future: The Game is an exploration of Doc Brown's past, and how he became the eccentric genius scientist we know him as in the movies. After tracking down Doc following a journey gone a bit awry, Marty McFly's stuck juggling multiple eras of Doc and eventually having to deal with a much different Doc than he's used to. The consequences of minor changes are even more evident this time around than they were in the films, though the quests to fix those changes show a wide variety of Hill Valleys that were and could have been.First things first, I need to commend all the performers they got to fill the various roles. Marty McFly's voice actor is a dead ringer for 80's-era Michael J. Fox, and the rest of the familiar cast is well-represented. New characters abound without overwhelming familiar faces, and are all established firmly enough that you care about them, be it out of love or of loathing. It's nice that the game manages to give Marty's history some time in the spotlight as well, despite all the focus on Doc.Progress in the game is based primarily on conversation, working your way through options to figure out what's going on, what to do next, and how to get people to do what you need. There are several points where this can get tedious and/or unclear as to how to proceed, but those bits are few and far between, especially as you get into the later episodes. There's a bit of item collection and use, but it takes a back seat to the dialogue trees, which makes for a great showcase of Telltale's writing skill. Action sequences pop up from time to time as well, which add to the cinematic feel of the game but are also the weakest, gameplay-wise. Several times, I found myself going in circles trying to figure out how to finish an action sequence, only to find I was missing a single, relatively tiny (visually and figuratively) piece of the puzzle. I guess my best advice for these bits is to look up. Always look up.Other than that, Back to the Future: The Game is absolutely worth your time. A fitting tribute to the films, these five episodes could easily be considered canon if they aren't already.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												There are two ways to look at this game. One way is if your a fan of Telltale games. The other is if you are a back to the future fan. In this case, I am the later half. Telltale perspective: I have played their more well know games such as TWD (both seasons) and The Wolf Among us. Both of which felt a little more creative. The Game also took me about 10 hours which seemed a little short for their games. The one thing that stuck out the most was that if you played their other games, get ready for a change, granted this is one of the first game like TWD or any such, so do cut it some slack.Back to the Future Perspective: Let me start off by saying I LOVE these movies (yes, even part 3). Had they decided to make a part 4, this would have worked in my opinion. They refrence the movies through out the episodes and try to stay true to everyones personalities in them. I was also surprised to see Christopher Lloyd play Doc Brown throught the whole game and see Micheal J. Fox play William Mcfly (Marty's Great grandpa). They even got Tom Wilson to voice Biff on home consoles. How ever there were a fair share of things that couldve been fixed/ would be nice but not need to fix. (No spoilers) The end of episode 5 completly falls apart and then leaves it on a cliff hanger most notably.There is rumor that the sequal is being made, but is bottem on the priority list, but hopefully Telltale will publish it soon.Overall, I would say definitly try it your a BttF fan, even if you dont like it, you'll probably like some of the refrences to the movies. It certainly beats BttF on NES. Its a maybe for you Telltale fans, like I said, this was the first of their style of games. But regarless of what you think, where you're going, you dont need roads

Posted: January 23, 2016
												My son and I just finished playing through the game.  We both thoroughly enjoyed the story - it was like watching Back to the Future part IV!  If you are in any way a fan of these wonderful movies, we recommend that you play all five episodes.  It was great just for the story alone.  As a kid who saw all three movies in the theater, it was a special treat for me.  I only wish I could have seen this in the theater as well, but this is the next best thing.  Thank you TellTale for a great story.  I now consider the story told in this game as part of the Back to the Future story.  Five Stars! Grade A+!

Posted: February 14, 2016
												Date: 2/13/16Review Number: 16 (Bank Review #2)Game: Back to the Future Episode 1From (Creator Publisher): Telltale GamesPlayed On: Steambox (Steam Controller)Steam Price as of Review:Total Time played: 2+ Hours (Wife observing for all of it)Review:For the second review of the vacation, I decided to do something else a bit different.   Now a bit of personal info here, I am married (have been for a decade) and my wife, though not exactly crazy about video games, does enjoy a round or two of some games in my collection.  After she was finished with a round, and since there was nothing on TV, I decided to take over for a round.  Looking through a collection for something we both would enjoy, my choice was quickly overridden when my wife noticed that I had a Back to the Future adventure game.  So we took the time to fire up Telltale Game’s Back to the Future episode 1, a point and click adventure game with so many of the original cast and staff involved that it might as well be considered a sequel of sorts, though granted some thirty years afterwards.  And sequel this very well could be; the writing is superb, the voices so on par, with many of the original characters playing themselves (sans the main character, though Michael J Fox does do some cameo appearances as the non-1985-prime McFly family) this is in many ways a continuation of the Back to the Future series that works well in-canon.  The graphics are pretty, and the animations are fantastic.  The controls are fantastic, and work surprisingly well with the Steam Gamepad.  The only part of the interface that I thought was a little odd was the inventory screen, but even with that, I found that the game parts of the game were so unobtrusive that I could often just ‘go through the motions’ of playing the game and feel like I was just watching a movie.  Indeed, if someone is looking for a more robust ‘adventure’ game, they may find this game somewhat lacking for that reason. Even with a  lot of interactable objects in each area, the game still feels like you only head in one direction, moving along a very specific course with interactable objects proving just a bit of flair.  In the end though, this game is a beautiful continuation of a fantastic movie series, and I fully intend to play this all the way through to it's conclusion. Anyone who loves the movies, or loves point and click adventure games, will eat this up.  Buy buy buy! Game’s Fate: Kept on the Steambox, will occasionally play itBuy/No Buy: If you like point and click adventure games, this one isn’t necessarily the most difficult or engaging, but it's enjoyable enough, and fans of the movies will love them.  Buy.

												A surprisingly fun game, even though I'm not the biggest fan of point-and-click adventure games. The plot is silly at times, but fun nonetheless, and the characters are interesting.I felt a little confined as all five games mostly revolve around one square in town in different timelines and there wasn't that many secondary interactive elements, plus you aren't given any real choices. However, the dialogs are complex enough and puzzles are diverse enough to keep you interested.From the technical point of view, it's mediocre. Voice acting is good, graphics and animation are outdated, camera control is terrible. I mean, it'll easily win the contest for the most messed up camera - you'll find camera switching between three views from completely different directions when you move mouse cursor and the main character looks in different directions. Controller is pretty much unusable as it's close to impossible to click precisely.Overall, if you're a fan of Back to the Future even in a slightest, you don't want to miss the game, but it does have some rough edges.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												This review concerns the whole series of Back to the Future.TL,DR; I had a blast with the series and recommend it, more easily so if you liked the movies.+ Telltale game engine+ Back to the Future theme+ Voice actor A.J. Locascio very closely resembles Fox's voice from the movies+ Overall good voice acting+ Believable characters+ Hours of nostalgia0 Puzzles of medium challenge- (the old) Too short, about 2 hours for each of the 5 episodesFirst off, the game uses the Telltale[en.wikipedia.org] tool known from adventures like the three new Sam & Max serieses, The Walking Dead, the current Tales from the Borderlands and a number of lesser known games, e.g. Puzzle Agent.Except for maybe the awful Bone series the tool generally provides easily navigable good-looking scenery. It manages too closely resemble the respective flair and art style of the basic IPs.Same with this adventure, I was seamlessly brought back to the 1985 setting, then gleefully thrown about. The voice acting did it's part with A.J. Locascio closely imitating Micheal J. Fox's pitch and tremble from the movies.Characters are believably written and we get to learn more about the McFlys, Browns and Tannens.The puzzles are not too hard and most of the time logical and with clear intent. This though adds to the episodes being somewhat short. I think I spent around 2 hours per episode making the series roughly a 10 hour experience - an experience of awesome.Thank you, Telltale, for once more providing a high-class adventure and letting me dive back into the atmosphere of Back to the Future including feelings of hope for and fear of the technology of the future.Also, the future is now! 2015 is only days away. I hear self-tightening shoes have been done and the hoverboard works if only just. Now, where is the self-drying jacket and the convincing shark hologram?Five episodes of Back to the Future adventure and reminiscence. Recommended.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Pros: - Young Doc was terribly adorable.- I appreciated that Christopher Lloyd reprised his role as Doc (and MFox did a cameo in Ep 5)- The Opening/Ending mirrored the movies (which made everything feel lovely)- The story was interesting - Playing the game got easier to navigate Cons:- The story stopped being interesting after Ep 3- It was hard to control Marty in Eps 1/2- Ep 5 can be summarized as: 'finding/killing doc then being the inbetweener between a familly argument because no one is willing to talk to one another' (no spoilers in that sentence, don't worry)- Ep 3 can be summarized as 'doing nothing while you run around talking to people then the story ends'- The animation was so off at times. Sometimes simple things like a WALK CYCLE was not done correctly and Marty looked like he was walking with straight legs- Sometimes the animation stops or the dialogue stops while the animation catches up- The ending feels like an absolute cop outI know this is one of TellTales older games but I was expecting development from ep1 to ep5 (such as game mechanics getting better). But it feels unpolished. Simple things, such as making sure that a walking cycle looks believable shouldn't be neglected in any game, even if it's coming from an indie developer.  I really love Back to the Future but this didn't feel like what the franchise deserved. It's more of a causal game than an 'adventure game' since I basically did nothing but walk Marty from place to place. tl;dr: Doc gets a new girlfriend and then the story gets dull. The end.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												This Telltale-Game is a pretty sweet sequel to the movie franchise.StoryIn 1986 you play as Marty and witness how Doc's properties are being sold and suddenly the DeLorean appears which gives to the clue that the real Doc has problems in the past and you must help him.And of course like in the movies you will stumble in some excellent adventures (...oh wrong movie :D) including changing the past and the future.Without spoiling to much of the storyline:you will go back to the year 1931 than back to an alternate 1986 and of course back to 1931 and a little bit of the wildwest (only a few moments at the end of the game).The whole story will be told in 5 episodes. (You get all 5 episodes with one buy.)Every episode will end with a twist and a short look to the next episode.The graphics......are nicely done.You don't need a high end cpu to run this game.The characters and environment have a comic book design which looks pretty sweet and you recognize all the characters from the movies.The gameplay......is really simple as you just do point and click und move with mouse or keyboard.The soundtrack......is awesome but hey, its just the same themes as in the movies!!!I'm glad they got the rights and didn't use new themes because otherwise it would be horrible.The voice acting...The voice actors are doing a good job.Christopher Lloyd as Doc Brown is the only actor from the movies who does the voice acting on this game.All the other characters are beeing dubbed by different actors.AJ Locascio does a an amazing job portraiting Marty McFly.Michael J. Fox has a voice cameo in the 5th episode!!Only two cons:- no achievemnts- no trading cardsI totally recommend it for young and mature people who love the Back to the Future movies!!

If you're not a die-hard fan, or unsure if you'll really enjoy this, buy this while it's still on sale.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												This game is a must have for fans of the movie trilogy and just fans of these types of point and click games in general. It has quite a few flaws that i will detail below, but the good triumphs over the bad if the game is on sale. Good aspects:Detailed and well thought out story that links all five episodes together - Each story has logical and believable writing and execution in relation to the movies. The motives of the characters is similar to that of what was in the movies and it is told well enough.Great voice acting/dialogue/characters - the person portraying Marty sounds so similar to Mr. Fox in the movies that i kept on actually believing that it really was him doing his best vocal impression of himself at that young age. Christopher Lloyd was also a delight to listen to. As were the other lead characters for the most part. Nostalgia - The game nails it when it comes to bringing memories back from the movies,  referencing certain aspects of the three movies and just celebrating the most memorable lines, moments and scenes in the movie trilogy without over doing it. Bad aspects:Presentation/animation - The character renders and overall presentation is quite bad in comparison to other games that celebrate famous movies (such as Ghostbusters: The Video Game, which came out a year earlier and which looked well detailed and thorogh in its visual appearance snd actually lets you roam around freely with very few issues) Roaming around in the Hill Valley in this game can seem like somewhat of a chore at times with the limitations on where you can walk and the camera angles nearly impossoble to manouvere. That doesn't change whether you use the keyboard controls or your mouse. The design of Hill Valley looks decent enough, but the whole presentation and animations of the chatacters could have been way better if the right time and money was invested. Still, it was still ok and not game breaking for me. Graphically, the game doesn't look as if it reaches its potential.Choice-based gameplay being limited - The choices that they let your character make are very limiting and don't really add much to your path in the story because whichever options you pick, your character will ultimately go always go in the same path. That is because with the options they provide you during interaction with various characters, you almost always have to pick all of them to move forward in the story. For example, playing as Marty, as you're interacting with Doc Brown you need to find out a specific piece of information and are given four or more choices of questions or phrases you can ask/provide, but you have to ask pretty much all of them to get to where you need to so there isn't really a huge amount of choice involved in actuality.Overall, it is a very good game for what it is that would be most enjoyed if you're a fan of the movie series that could have been amazing if a little more time and money were invested into this. Probably not worth it for the full price, but is great value when on sale.However, if they released a sequel to this (whether in episodic format or otherwise), then i would definitely buy it especially if they fixed the flaws that were in this game.

Posted: February 16
												This review is for the entire series, not just this episode.--------------Back To The Future The Game is a great video game and worth every penny if you enjoy point and click action/adventure puzzle story games.I watched the animated series & movies and they have since become three of my favorites. when I heard there was a game coming out and it was going to be an adventure game developed by Telltale responsible for Monkey Island and Sam & Max. I knew I needed to play this game. I was so exciting.Positives:The game features great voice work from Christopher Lloyd returning as Doc, and A.J. Locascio who did an awesome job as Marty, due to Michael J. Fox being unable to perform. Michael J. Fox has a cameo later in the game, and it's very nice.graphics are great, The character designs fit very well. The animation in the game is very good. Gameplay itself is simple, the puzzles are dialogue-based or involve using items with a great help system that'll ease players who are having trouble.Sound and music are very pleasing and make you feel like you're watching the old movies. Conclusion:Highly recommended for anyone who liked the movies, you'll like this game, It is true to the story.

Posted: February 5
												For fans of the movies, there really isn't much of a choice other than to play this series. "Back to the Future: The Game" is one of TellTale's earlier games, and it shows, with very limited choices and a linear story. The story itself also hews close to the original trilogy, down to the same feel when it comes to the final resolution.Voice acting isn't bad. Christopher Lloyd is around to voice Doc Brown, and Michael J. Fox makes a cameo near the end. They got other voice actors to play everyone else (including Marty McFly and the various Biffs), but they do a decent job. The music is great, right out of the movies. To be honest, if you go into this game expecting to be playing the movie (or an episode of the animated series), you'll know what you're in for.I really enjoyed this series back when it first came out, but it isn't as good as TellTale's later attempts.

Posted: January 1
												BTTFTG is firstly a puzzle game, secondly a narrative. I personally thought the narrative was more intriguing than the puzzles because they were getting kinda frustrating (knowing exactly what you need to do but not knowing the specific way of triggering it). Despite the frustration, however, the story kept me going because I wanted to see where it was going.While I found it enjoyable, and I would recommend it, you have to realise that this predates the Telltale Games where you actually get to make decisions that change the story. There are no branching decisions, simply following the narrative. It is not the best Telltale Game ever, but it's an enjoyable one.What really stands out for me was how messed up the time travel started getting, but because each episode is about two hours, you can follow it easily because each episode only adds one layer to the mess which is what lets it reach the chaotic climax.That being said, I wouldn't spend full price on it. But does anyone really buy games on Steam except during sales??

Posted: February 16
												This review is for the entire series, not just this episode.--------------Back To The Future The Game is a great video game and worth every penny if you enjoy point and click action/adventure puzzle story games.I watched the animated series & movies and they have since become three of my favorites. when I heard there was a game coming out and it was going to be an adventure game developed by Telltale responsible for Monkey Island and Sam & Max. I knew I needed to play this game. I was so exciting.Positives:The game features great voice work from Christopher Lloyd returning as Doc, and A.J. Locascio who did an awesome job as Marty, due to Michael J. Fox being unable to perform. Michael J. Fox has a cameo later in the game, and it's very nice.graphics are great, The character designs fit very well. The animation in the game is very good. Gameplay itself is simple, the puzzles are dialogue-based or involve using items with a great help system that'll ease players who are having trouble.Sound and music are very pleasing and make you feel like you're watching the old movies. Conclusion:Highly recommended for anyone who liked the movies, you'll like this game, It is true to the story.
